title: Capacity Enhancement of a Radial Distribution Grid Using Smart Transformer
abstract: Distributed generation (DG) and electric vehicle (EV) are increasingly installed in the modern microgrids (MGs). This demands for an improvement in the power handling capacity of the existing distribution feeders. The power handling capacity of a feeder is limited by the voltage magnitude violation caused by overloading. The smart transformer (ST) is proposed as an effective solution for improving the performance of modern MG. This paper utilizes the power management capabilities of the ST with an integrated battery energy storage system (BESS) for improving the power handling capacity of a medium voltage (MV) 5-bus radial feeder. The proposed method demonstrates the ST's capability to control the active and/or reactive power flow at the MV grid for maintaining the steady-state voltage magnitude within the grid-specified limit. A sensitivity analysis based design study is proposed to determine the power rating requirements for different ST and BESS converters during distinct power control scenarios. The analysis shows the capability of ST in injecting/absorbing active and reactive powers in flexible combinations for achieving the desired voltage magnitudes. The findings are verified through simulation and experimental results.

ABSTRACT Distributed generation (DG) and electric vehicle (EV) are increasingly installed in the modern
microgrids (MGs). This demands for an improvement in the power handling capacity of the existing
distribution feeders. The power handling capacity of a feeder is limited by the voltage magnitude violation
caused by overloading. The smart transformer (ST) is proposed as an effective solution for improving the
performance of modern MG. This paper utilizes the power management capabilities of the ST with an
integrated battery energy storage system (BESS) for improving the power handling capacity of a medium
voltage (MV) 5-bus radial feeder. The proposed method demonstrates the ST’s capability to control the
active and/or reactive power ﬂow at the MV grid for maintaining the steady-state voltage magnitude within
the grid-speciﬁed limit. A sensitivity analysis based design study is proposed to determine the power rating
requirements for different ST and BESS converters during distinct power control scenarios. The analysis
shows the capability of ST in injecting/absorbing active and reactive powers in ﬂexible combinations for
achieving the desired voltage magnitudes. The ﬁndings are veriﬁed through simulation and experimental
results.
INDEX TERMS Power handling capacity, power management, smart transformer (ST).
I. INTRODUCTION
The penetration of distributed generation (DG) sources and
electric vehicles (EVs) are increasing rapidly in the mod-
ern power system [1], [2]. Accommodating the additional
load/generation in the exiting feeders without violating the
grid-code speciﬁed power quality limits is a major challenge.
Violation of steady-state voltage magnitude limits restricts
the higher load/DG inclusion in existing feeders. In order
to improve the static hosting capability of feeders, several
power management methods are proposed in the literature.
The PV hosting capabilities of the distribution feeder are
improved using static compensator (STATCOMs) [3] and
battery energy storage system (BESS) [4], [5]. The EV load
hosting capability improvement in a low voltage (LV) distri-
bution grid is realized using distributed phase-shifting control
[2]. The voltage sensitivity factors indicate the dependence
of bus voltage magnitudes for a corresponding change in the

active and the reactive powers at a particular bus [6]. These
factors are used to control the voltage rise by managing the
active power ﬂow from PV sources in radial distribution grids
[7]. In [8], the sensitivity factors are utilized for enhancing the
load/generation hosting capacity of a distribution system with
the help of dc interconnection and BESS.
In the distribution grid with substantial DG and BESS
installations, the smart transformer (ST) has emerged as a
suitable solution for their integration and power management
related problems [9]–[11]. The ST is a power electronics-
based transformer with various functionalities in addition to
the features of the conventional power transformer (CPT)
[12]. The volume and weight reduction is one of the main
hardware gain achieved by the employment of ST. How-
ever, in the distribution system applications, the volume and
weight reduction impact is relatively small, and the efﬁciency,
reliability plays an important role [11]. Therefore, in order
to justify the higher cost involved with ST, more services
are required to be incorporated with it. The medium voltage
(MV) and LV dc link connectivity is one service, which ST

can offer in comparison with CPT. The dc-link connectivity
enables the reactive power decoupling of MV and LV ac
sides. Moreover, the dc links are utilized to connect electric
vehicles, renewable sources, battery storage, etc. [13]. The
reactive power-decoupling feature is utilized for maintain-
ing the unity power factor currents at the MV AC side [11].
The ST also can maintain the balanced sinusoidal voltage
at the LV AC grid irrespective of the load nature. Harmonic
compensation capability is also another feature available with
the ST MV converter to improve MV ac current quality.
Unlike CPT, ST is embedded with the fault isolation and
current limitation control functions [10]. A detailed design
and analysis of 100 kV A solid state transformer (SST) in a
distribution system is presented in [14]. Reverse power ﬂow
control capability of ST helps in controlling the voltage rise in
the MV grid [15]. The load control capability of ST is utilized
as a power reserve during grid frequency ﬂuctuation [16].
The SST is used for interfacing the wind energy conversion
system with the grid in place of CPT [17].
The hosting capability improvement using STATCOM is
effective in distribution grids with a low R/X ratio since it
utilizes the reactive power exchange. Similarly, BESS based
systems are effective in the resistive grids. Utilization of dc
lines for active power transfer involves the construction of
extra dc infrastructure parallel to ac line. The application
of PV converters for capacity enhancement involves active
power curtailment and this reduces the overall power extrac-
tion from the available solar energy. The reactive power
injection capability of ST has been explored for providing
voltage support. The MV grid voltage support is achieved
utilizing the reactive power injection of ST in [19]. The BESS
is integrated to the LVDC link of ST and used for peak
load shaving operation [20], and MV and LV voltage con-
trol [21]. However, in [20], the BESS charging/discharging
efﬁciency analysis is carried out with an ST based system.
In addition, the BESS is used to support LV loads of ST
during MV grid voltage sags. Moreover, no investigation is
carried out for improving the performance of the MV grid.
The ST integrated with BESS has the capability for ﬂexible
active and reactive power exchange with the MV grid. This
potential is not explored in the literature for improving the

a method to enhance the hosting capability of a 5-bus radial
distribution system using the power management features of
BESS integrated ST. A detailed study is carried out using

The organization of this paper is as follows. Section II
describes the system conﬁguration and sensitivity analy-

Section IV . Principle of operation of power converters is

Section VI. The experimental analysis is given in Section VII.
Section VIII provides the conclusions of the paper.
II. SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
AND SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS
In the ﬁrst part of this section, the conventional and pro-
posed radial distribution system structures are explained. In
the second part, an introduction to the sensitivity analysis is
provided.
A. SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
Fig. 1(a) shows the single-line diagram of an 11-kV (L-L),
5-bus, radial distribution feeder derived from [18]. The R/X
ratio of the distribution system is considered to be 0.85 [22]
with Weasel conductor and other parameters are given in
Table 1. In each bus, loads and DG are connected through
11/0.4 kV CPT. The uniform variation of loads and gen-
eration at all buses are considered in this paper to analyze
the extreme voltage drop/rise scenarios [8], [23]–[25]. The

B. SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS
Newton-Raphson load-ﬂow is carried out for the system
shown in Fig. 1(b) to determine the voltages at each bus.
Bus-0 is assumed as slack bus, and voltage magnitude is
considered as 1 p.u. At bus-4, ST absorbs only active power
from the grid, and no reactive power is exchanged with the
MV grid. Sensitivity analysis helps in identifying the effect
of active and reactive powers on the various bus voltages.
In this paper, the sensitivity coefﬁcients are derived from
Jacobian matrix of Newton-Raphson load-ﬂow method. The
loading on bus-1 to bus-4 is uniformly increased from zero at

magnitudes are plotted in Fig. 3. For analyzing the worst
loading condition, generation at all the buses is considered
as zero. From Fig. 3, it is observed that the bus-4 experiences
worst voltage variations. Therefore, the objective of this paper
is to improve the voltage at bus-4 and thereby improving
the load hosting capability. The change in voltage at bus-

III. SIZING BASED ON SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS
DURING LOAD INCREASE
This section consists of four sub-sections. In the ﬁrst part, the
system operating conditions based on the load-ﬂow studies
are explained, which are the basis for sizing analysis. In the
other three sub-sections, the sizing of converters involved is
detailed using sensitivity studies under three different operat-
ing scenarios. In the ﬁrst method, only reactive power injec-
tion from ST is considered, and in the second, only active
power injection is considered. In the third sub-section, the
combination of active and reactive power is utilized to attain
the desired objective.

A. SYSTEM OPERATING CONDITIONS
In the proposed method, the ST integrated with BESS is
controlled to manage the power ﬂow at the MV grid for
improving the load hosting capability of the feeder. It can be
observed that the maximum active power loading is limited to
approximately 0.29 p.u. due to the violation of voltage limit
(0.9 p.u.), and the same is marked in Fig. 3. The steady-state
voltage variations in a distribution system are not allowed
beyond a maximum of 1.1 p.u. and a minimum of 0.9 p.u.,
respectively [30]. Therefore, if the bus-4 voltage is within
these limits, the ST is operated in normal operating mode,
and if the limits are violated, it is operated in voltage con-
trol mode. This paper considers active and/or reactive power
control only at bus-4 using BESS integrated ST. The worst
bus voltage magnitude considered for analysis in this paper is
0.85 p.u. Therefore, the maximum load hosting capability that
can be achieved is the load corresponding to 0.85 p.u. of bus-
4 voltage. From Fig. 3, the voltage at bus-4 is 0.85 p.u. when
the active power loading on all the buses are 0.41 p.u. The
rating of converters is decided to improve the voltage during
this maximum voltage scenario. For the analysis, losses in the
converters are neglected.
The ST LV converter supplies the load at the LV AC side
in bus-4. In all the considered cases, the maximum active
power loading is 0.41 p.u. at a lagging power factor of 0.95.
Therefore, the ST LV converter is rated at 0.432. p.u.

IV. SIZING BASED ON SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS DURING
GENERATION INCREASE
In this section, the sizing analysis is brieﬂy analyzed when
the generation is increased along the feeder. Newton-Raphson
load-ﬂow is carried out for the system shown in Fig. 1(b)
to determine the voltages at each bus. Bus-0 is assumed as
slack bus, and voltage magnitude is considered as 1 p.u. In
this case, the generation at each bus is increased uniformly
and the reverse power ﬂow condition is analyzed. Due to
reverse power ﬂow along the feeder, the voltages increases
in different buses and Fig. 4 shows the variation of voltages
at different buses when generation is increased from zero.
For analyzing the worst voltage rise phenomenon, the loading
at all the buses is assumed as zero. From Fig. 4, it can
be observed that the maximum active power generation is
limited approximately to 0.46 p.u. due to the violation of
the upper voltage limit (1.1 p.u.), and the same is marked
in the plot. The STs’ capability to improve the load hosting
capability can also be utilized for increasing DG penetra-
tion. The sensitivity study explained in case of load host-
ing capability improvement is repeated for the generation
increase.
As seen in Fig. 4, the bus-4 experiences the worst voltage
magnitude rise due to increased generation. The worst bus
voltage magnitude considered for analysis in this paper is
1.125 p.u. Therefore, the maximum DG hosting capabil-
ity that can be achieved is the generation corresponding to
1.125 p.u. of bus-4 voltage. From Fig. 4, the voltage at bus-4
is 1.125 p.u. when the active power generation on all the buses
is 0.59 p.u. This condition is considered to decide the size of
different converters. The sensitivity-based sizing is explained
for the load increase case, and the same methods are repeated
for generation increase. The essential ﬁndings related to the
ratings of different converters are tabulated in Table 3.
The third scenario shown in the above analysis considers
the equal contribution of active and reactive power injection.
However, the ST is capable of operating at other combinations
of active and reactive powers to improve the voltage at bus-4.
In another way, this ﬂexible active, reactive power injection
shows the multiple power factor operation capability of ST
for achieving the same objective.

VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
The simulation study is carried out in the PSCAD environ-
ment. The system parameters used for simulation studies
are given in Table 1, Table 4, and Table 5. Loading on all
the four buses are considered to be uniform throughout the
simulation study at a constant lagging power factor of 0.95.
The ST is installed at the bus-4, and the active power load
hosting capability of each bus is limited to 0.29 p.u. due to
the violation of steady-state voltage limit (0.9 p.u.) at bus-4
as obtained from the load-ﬂow studies. The aim is to improve
the active power load hosting capability to 0.41 p.u., which
corresponds to 0.85 p.u. of voltage at bus-4 without any
active/reactive power support from ST. The active/reactive
power requirement from ST in different control strategies
is explained in the above section, and the simulation results

VIII. CONCLUSION
In this paper, the CPT is replaced with a BESS integrated ST
in a 5-bus radial MV distribution system. The load hosting
capability improvement is achieved with three methods utiliz-
ing the STs’ multidimensional active and reactive power man-
agement capability. The design study based on the sensitivity
analysis provides the rating requirement for achieving the
desired results. The ﬁndings are veriﬁed through simulation
and experimental results.
